docs.lead_paragraph: At the end of the Democratic convention in August, after feminists had succeeded in passing minority reports to strengthen the platform's support of the proposed equal rights amendment and of Federal funds for abortions, Eleanor Smeal was discussing the impact of the convention's rule requiring equal representation of female delegates. ''The other day I was asked if having 50 percent women delegates would make a difference,'' said Mrs. Smeal, president of the National Organization for Women. ''I think we have now answered that question.''

headline.main: Women in Office: How Have They Affected Women's Issues?; News Analysis Impact of Officeholders A Substantive Role One Woman's Record Appointments Seen as Vital Women Want Broader Role

docs.abstract: Article on impact of increasing numbers of women in public office notes their pronounced concern for women's rights and opportunities, and Repr Elizabeth Holtzman's assertion that 'vast majority' of new bills affecting status of women are introduced by women

docs.lead_paragraph: uf913A S the 1980 election campaign ends, many questions remain unanswered. Mine is, who will slay the sacred cows? The United States has accumulated a large herd of untouchable economic institutions. Every four years, our Presidential candidates promise to thin the herd by cutting waste, but no single cow is labeled overweight or unnecessary. In addition, during the campaign, the candidates usually point to additional necessary heifers - this year's being an increase in the fraction of the gross national herd devoted to defending the range. Because of the asymmetry between birth and death of sacred cows, there is a consensus that the reach of Federal programs has become excessive, yet we cannot take significant steps to trim the Federal sector.

headline.main: IT'S TIME TO SLAY THE SACRED COWS

headline.main: ECONOMIC AFFAIRS; It's Time to Slay the Sacred Cows

docs.abstract: Prof William Nordhaus article on untouchable economic institutions, which he says have become excessive and in need of reform; lists 8, including what he says is most ancient of our sacred cows: outmoded economic regulatory activities that inhibit play of market forces; sketch (M)
